image.altText: People stand on a stage.

items.synopsis: The prestigious National NAIDOC Week Awards Ceremony is underway in Brisbane and 10 winners will soon be recognised for their triumphs.

title.children: Former AFL star takes out Innovation Award as NAIDOC Week ceremony names winners

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Gunaikurnai marine science student, Courtney Burns, has been named Youth of the Year. She has dedicated her university degree and career to change the relationship humans have with sharks by bringing First Nations culture and history into science literature. "NAIDOC Youth of the Year — that has a deadly ring to it, I reckon!" she says. "I just wanted to thank my guide, absolutely awesome. Hearing what you have achieved is super inspiring. I just want to thank everyone who has got me to where I am today. "This is actually gnarly. I'm going to keep it short and sweet. Thank you so much guys and for our Elders ." Burns has previously been recognised as an innovator in her field, receiving several awards, including the Google Future Leaders in STEM Scholarhip and CSIRO for Academic Excellence .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Marine scientist named Youth of the Year

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Although he's known for his AFL career, Daniel Motlop is fiercely passionate about native foods. The proud Larrakia man from Darwin is the co-founder of Something Wild Australia, an Indigenous owned company that supplies native ingredients like magpie goose, green ants, Kakadu plums and bush apples to restaurants and supermarkets across the nation. Motlop was emotional when he accepted the Innovation Award : "That is a bit overwhelming. I didn't think I'd be standing here 10 years out of football and accepting an award for food ," he says. "I'd like to thank the NAIDOC committee ... You run a business and obviously try to make profit and make money, and try to be better for your family. "You don't want to just be seen as an Indigenous business, so I tried to really elevate that and become a mainstream business in what we do, whether it be a green ant in bush apple gin — things that are native to Australia — we put them in a commercial product so people can try them and take them and make them the norm ."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former AFL star takes out Innovation Award

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Aunty Dr Matilda House-Williams has been welcomed to the stage to receive the next award, the Female Elder Award. A treasure of her community, Aunty Dr Matilda was instrumental in founding the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in 1972 and helped establish the Aboriginal Legal Service. "I want to thank all my family. Thankyou. Thank you," she said as she took to the stage. Aunty Dr Matilda was nominated for the resilience she helps to build in young people and the way she gives to her community.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Female Elder Award goes to Aunty Dr Matilda House-Williams

children.content: Ngambri, Wallabalooa and Wiradyuri Elder, Dr House-Williams is a powerhouse for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander advocacy.
Aunty Dr Matilda House-Williams has been welcomed to the stage to receive the next award, the Female Elder Award.
A treasure of her community, Aunty Dr Matilda was instrumental in founding the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in 1972 and helped establish the Aboriginal Legal Service.
"I want to thank all my family. Thankyou. Thank you," she said as she took to the stage.
Aunty Dr Matilda was nominated for the resilience she helps to build in young people and the way she gives to her community.

image.altText: Albanese smiles in the cold dawn light, the warm colour of a grand autumnal tree fills the background behind him.

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese believes Australians will welcome the news of a larger than expected budget surplus even as their own budgets continue to take a battering.

title.children: Prime minister spruiks large budget surplus as Australian households battle cost-of-living crisis

image.altText: Vladimir Putin's face is lit by warm sunlight. He wears dark sunglasses and a black jacket on black shirt

items.synopsis: As the war grinds on and the traitor Yevgeny Prigozhin is allowed to live on in exile, the question must be asked: Is Vladimir Putin losing his grip on power?

title.children: Russia's elites have a plan in case Putin is toppled. Here's how it could happen

image.altText: A group of helmeted police officers walk with riot shields during a protest, lit by bright yellow street light.

items.synopsis: France's interior ministry says the fourth night of clashes between mostly young protesters and police was less violent than the previous night but more arrests were made, as President Emmanuel Macron urges parents to keep their kids off the streets and the government asks social media companies to help identify those fomenting violence.

title.children: French police arrest almost 1,000 people in fourth night of unrest

image.altText: A woman resting her chin on her hand smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Millions of Australians are opting for career changes, but experts say the window may be closing to get the most out of the "Great Reshuffle". This is how mid-career professionals jumped at the chance for an occupation transformation and set themselves up for a more fulfilling work future.

title.children: Would you take a $50,000 pay cut? Why these mid-career professionals aren't looking back

image.altText: Steve Smith holds his pose after playing a cover drive

items.synopsis: Australia resumes its second batting innings with a lead of 221 runs over England on day four at Lord's. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Australia looking to pile on runs on day four of second Ashes Test at Lord's

image.altText: Birds fly out the front of Parliament House

items.synopsis: For years, debate has raged in the nation's capital about the need for a federal anti-corruption watchdog — one with actual teeth. Now the National Anti-Corruption Commission is here, so what will it achieve?

title.children: The army major general turned federal anti-corruption boss officially starts today — what's ahead of him?

image.altText: Girl looking straight at camera with spinifex bush in background.

items.synopsis: Kira Gusterson heard rumours of a "Pilbara tax" before she moved to the iron ore mining region — but she was still shocked by the cost of living.

title.children: Living in a mining town when you're not on a mining wage

image.altText: Two women in 1800s period-costume dresses walk past timber huts.

items.synopsis: Jack Yabsley, a former presenter of Saturday Disney and Totally Wild, describes his new TV series Gold Diggers as an anti-patriarchal, "grubby, political, silly, sexy comedy".

title.children: Former kids' TV presenter creates bawdy comedy about women on Australia's goldfields

image.altText: Pat Cummins lies on his back while completing a catch, Josh Hazlewood pumps his fist and Jonny Bairstow watches on

items.synopsis: With the match in the balance on the third morning, an incredible display of irresponsible English batting gifted Australia the ascendancy and again raised questions about the validity of the host's tactical approach.

title.children: England's absurd batting gifts Australia Ashes advantage and puts Bazball in the firing line

image.altText: A headshot of a young woman with blonde hair looking off camera.

items.synopsis: Police searching for missing Belgian tourist Celine Cremer say a hiker in the area has responded to a plea to come forward to help with any further information about her movements.

title.children: Police searching for missing Belgian tourist speak to hiker about her movements at waterfall track

image.altText: Jim Chalmers sitting in the House of Representatives. He holds his hand over his mouth.

items.synopsis: The cost-of-living crisis cannot be resolved by one institution alone and raising interest rates isn't the only way to take money out of the economy, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Interest rates needn't be as high as they are, but the government would need to act, top economist says

image.altText: a cloud band forms over the kimberley

items.synopsis: Unseasonable rain continues to fall across Australia's north in what's meant to be the region's dry season, helping lower temperatures to near-record levels.

title.children: Why holiday-makers heading north for winter sun could be in for unpleasant surprise

image.altText: Port Adelaide forward Charlie Dixon sits on the ground and pumps his fist in celebration after kicking a goal during an AFL game

items.synopsis: It's a tight one at the MCG, with Port Adelaide edging ahead of Essendon at the main break, after the Magpies destroy the Suns' finals chances at Carrara, and the Crows and the Bulldogs get vital wins. Follow our live AFL ScoreCentre for all the scores, stats and results.

title.children: AFL live: Power, Bombers in close one at the MCG after Magpies masterclass, Crows and Bulldogs win

image.altText: A medium sized bird, patterned black, white and yellow, on a tree branch.

items.synopsis: There are fewer than 300 regent honeyeaters in the wild but after a concerning breeding season, conservationists are encouraged by recent sightings along the east coast.

title.children: Sightings of one of Australia's rarest birds spark hope, as fight to save species continues

image.altText: A white car with its front crashed into the underside of a rolled truck on a dark road

items.synopsis: Several crashes have occurred across South Australia this morning, including one where a station wagon allegedly "disregarded directions" from police at a road closure point and crashed into a rolled truck on the Dukes Highway.

title.children: One man dies as SA Police respond to multiple unrelated crashes across the state

image.altText: Afghanistan evacuation

items.synopsis: A report says decisions by US President Joe Biden and his predecessor Donald Trump to withdraw troops from Afghanistan had "serious consequences for the viability" of the former US-backed government.

title.children: Review into evacuation of US troops from Afghanistan critical of Biden, Trump

image.altText: Two women stand in front of an apple display at a supermarket and put them in a small plastic bag.

items.synopsis: The government is expanding a campaign against single-use plastics that it started in 2019, when it banned the thicker plastic shopping bags that customers used to carry home their grocery items.

title.children: New Zealand says it's the first to ban thin plastic bags from supermarkets

image.altText: Michael Bond stands next to his red car at night at a charging station.

items.synopsis: While the take-up of electric vehicles has surged in recent years, EV advocates say Victoria has fallen behind New South Wales in its spending on charging stations.

title.children: Australians are embracing electric vehicles in record numbers. But the switch isn't always cheap or easy

image.altText: a young man wearing a brimmed hat on a bench holding whips

items.synopsis: In a small Northern Territory town where the outback meets the tropics, Nathan Griggs is cracking his whips in time to Australian rock anthems.

title.children: Record-holding whip cracker shows NT tourists a cracking good time

image.altText: Aboriginal man with Aboriginal flag on a blue T-shirt on a balcony with the beach behind him.

items.synopsis: The collection of staged photographs from the 1900s depicting Birpai people in traditional dress and poses from a bygone era receives heritage listing.

title.children: A family secret led John to preserve heritage photos. But he needs help finding a mystery man

image.altText: Bright red lines coming out the top of a mountian.

items.synopsis: The sacred understanding of El Popo varies from town to town, but many agree that the volcano does not threaten their lives.

title.children: How a Mexican spiritual leader preserves the sacred knowledge of the volcano known as El Popo

image.altText: Sham wears a purple jumper while holding a jar at a dining table in a house

items.synopsis: It made perfect sense for Sham to start her own business while using her life experience to create accessible beauty products, as figures show people with disabilities are far more likely to be self employed.

title.children: Sham finds it easier to be her own boss while living with disabilities — and she is not alone

image.altText: A woman dressed in purple holding flowers supported by friends and family in purple

items.synopsis: After two decades of silence, Craig Rumsby confesses to the murder of Gulgong teenager Michelle Bright in 1999 and is found guilty.

title.children: 'I've waited 24 years for this': Michelle Bright's mother in tears as Dubbo court convicts killer

image.altText: The window of an Apple store with a large Apple logo on it

items.synopsis: The company, co-founded by Steve Jobs had briefly eclipsed a $US3 trillion market value on back-to-back days in January 2022, but couldn't hold on by the time the market closed.

title.children: Apple becomes first public company to close at $US3 trillion market value

image.altText: Stack of gold coins on a pink background

items.synopsis: With the start of the new financial year bringing no relief to unrelenting cost-of-living pressures, experts recommend you review your finances and set new budgets and goals.

title.children: The new financial year's begun — here's how to do a money reset and get a hold of your finances

image.altText: bus crash

items.synopsis: At least 25 people die after a bus crashes and bursts into flames in India's western state of Maharashtra.

title.children: India bus fire kills at least 25, injures eight

image.altText: a woman wearing a suit looks sideways

items.synopsis: News headlines about the corruption watchdog's findings against Gladys Berejiklian this week left many scratching their heads and wondering why she won't face any criminal charges for her conduct.

title.children: The 'heavy punishment' Gladys Berejiklian faces despite legal charges being ruled out

image.altText: The entrance to the District Court of Western Australia, with a tree to the right of frame.

items.synopsis: A man is jailed for "unthinkable" offences against his wife and young daughter, that included him taking them hostage and repeatedly raping both of them over a four-day period. WARNING: This story contains distressing content.

title.children: Perth man jailed for 30 years for 'depraved and cruel' sexual offences against wife, daughter

image.altText: Water falling over rock edge

items.synopsis: More than 50 million litres of water is permitted to be extracted from bores within a stone's throw from a UNESCO world heritage rainforest in the Gold Coast hinterland, as groups call for tighter regulation.

title.children: Water destined for plastic bottles is being pumped from beside this world heritage rainforest. Calls are growing for it to end

image.altText: Actor Alan arkin poses with his Oscar smiling gently, wearing a suit

items.synopsis: Tributes from Hollywood flood in after the actor's sons confirmed their father's death.

title.children: Oscar winner Alan Arkin dies at 89

image.altText: Wedge-tailed eagle in flight

items.synopsis: Australian raptors like the wedge-tailed eagle and peregrine falcon are natural predators of corellas and other cockatoos. Now they are being deployed to keep them away.

title.children: Is this the ultimate scarecrow to move marauding corellas on?

image.altText: - A person walks past a building which says Fox News.

items.synopsis: The payout to Abby Grossberg will settle all litigation she brought against Fox Corporation, Fox News Network and her former co-workers, including former Fox host Tucker Carlson.

title.children: Fox News reaches $18 million settlement with former producer who testified in Dominion case

image.altText: An illustration of a woman reading in bed, with a knitted sweater reading "heart ABC Arts".

items.synopsis: Need a good book to snuggle up with as temperatures drop? The stars of this June’s best books include a teacher on a road trip with a corpse, a novelist grappling with her mother’s funeral, and prisoners doomed to fight to the death.

title.children: ‘Quietly devastating’, ‘beautifully told’, a ‘blistering critique’: Five must-read books

image.altText: Prince Harry shows no emotion as he leaves the High Court in London.

items.synopsis: Prince Harry is seeking damages in relation to 33 articles and 61 instances of alleged unlawful information gathering.

title.children: Prince Harry seeks up to $843,000 in phone-hacking lawsuit against UK tabloid publisher
